stories.title: Two70: Where the Tech Actually Matters
stories.intended_reader: Travelers skeptical of cruise ship tech gimmicks
stories.core_insight: Two70's multimedia shows justify Quantum-class tech in ways most cruise features don't
stories.markdown:
I'm not easily impressed by cruise ship tech. Robot bartenders? Gimmick. Virtual balconies? Fine, but not transformative. Apps for everything? Annoying when they glitch.

But Two70 on Anthem delivered.

It's a two-story venue at the aft of the ship. During the day: floor-to-ceiling windows with stunning ocean views. Perfect for reading, coffee, quiet conversation. At night: those windows become video screens. Robotic screens descend from the ceiling. The space transforms into a multimedia theater.

The shows blend live performers (dancers, aerialists, musicians), video projections that cover walls and ceiling, and choreography that uses the entire space. It's immersive without being gimmicky. Theatrical without being cheesy.

I saw three different Two70 shows during my cruise. "Spectra's Cabaret" was the standout — live music, aerialists performing against shifting video backdrops, transitions that used the robotic screens to create depth and movement. My spouse (who hates cruise entertainment) leaned over mid-show: "This is actually good."

The tech *serves* the performance instead of replacing it. That's rare on cruise ships, where innovation often means "look what we can do" instead of "look what this enables."

Compare Two70 to the Bionic Bar (robotic bartenders): the robots are fun to watch once, but the drinks aren't better. Two70's tech makes the shows *better*—you couldn't create those performances without the video walls and robotic screens.

If you sail Anthem, don't skip Two70. Book show reservations early (seating fills fast). Arrive 10 minutes before showtime for good seats. And actually pay attention—this isn't background entertainment you half-watch while scrolling your phone.

See [other Quantum-class ships](/ships/rcl/quantum-of-the-seas.html) for similar Two70 venues: [Ovation](/ships/rcl/ovation-of-the-seas.html), [Spectrum](/ships/rcl/spectrum-of-the-seas.html), [Odyssey](/ships/rcl/odyssey-of-the-seas.html).

stories.title: My Daughter Flew Before She Could Drive
stories.intended_reader: Parents looking for meaningful family cruise experiences beyond waterslides
stories.core_insight: Anthem's RipCord by iFly creates breakthrough moments for kids that become family legends
stories.markdown:
**My daughter was terrified of heights. At thirteen, she wouldn't climb a ladder.**

So when she announced she wanted to try RipCord by iFly on Anthem, my wife and I exchanged glances. "Are you sure, honey?" She wasn't sure. But she wanted to try anyway.

RipCord is indoor skydiving — a vertical wind tunnel on the back of the ship. You wear a flight suit and goggles, and instructors teach you the basics: chin up, arms out, relax. Then you step into 100+ mph wind and... float. The first session is 60 seconds. Feels like 6.

Emma almost backed out three times. In the line. In the briefing room. At the chamber door. Each time, she'd look at us, take a breath, and keep going. The instructors were patient. They'd seen nervous kids before.

She stepped into that wind tunnel shaking.

Sixty seconds later, she came out grinning so hard she couldn't talk. The instructor had lifted her to the top of the chamber — thirty feet up — and she'd spread her arms like she was flying.

"Again," she said. "I want to go again."

We booked two more sessions. By the third, she was doing spins. The same kid who wouldn't climb a ladder was doing aerial maneuvers with wind whipping her ponytail.

That moment — watching her transform from terrified to triumphant — is worth more than any waterslide or wave pool. It's the story we tell at family dinners. It's the story she'll tell her kids someday.

**Practical notes:** RipCord fills up fast. Book your session the moment you board (go directly to the sports deck or use the app). Morning slots are less crowded. First-timers get a minute; return flyers can purchase longer sessions. There are weight and health restrictions — check Royal Caribbean's requirements before promising your kids.

See also: [SeaPlex](https://www.royalcaribbean.com/cruise-ships/anthem-of-the-seas) for bumper cars and roller skating, and [North Star](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html) for more perspective-changing moments.

stories.title: The Transatlantic We Almost Didn't Book
stories.intended_reader: Travelers considering transatlantic crossings or unusual itineraries
stories.core_insight: Anthem's transatlantic sailings offer rare uninterrupted sea days that transform the cruise experience
stories.markdown:
**My husband thought twelve days was too long. Five consecutive sea days? "We'll be bored," he said.**

We almost booked a standard Caribbean seven-nighter instead. Same ship, familiar ports, predictable rhythm. Safe choice.

But I'd always wanted to cross the Atlantic by ship. Something about that journey — the way travelers used to do it — felt meaningful. So I talked him into Southampton to Cape Liberty. Twelve nights. Five sea days in a row mid-voyage.

Those five days changed us.

Without ports to rush toward, we slowed down. We actually read books — whole books, not just airplane chapters. We had dinner conversations that lasted two hours because nobody was checking excursion times. We discovered the Solarium at 6am was nearly empty and became our morning coffee spot. We learned the bartenders' names.

Day three at sea, we hit weather. Not dangerous — just gray skies, choppy water, rain streaking the windows. On a port-heavy cruise, that's a disaster. On a transatlantic, it was cozy. We watched movies in the cabin, napped, had tea in the Schooner Bar while rain pelted the glass. Nowhere to be. Nothing to miss.

By day five, the rhythm had settled into us. Early wake-up. Solarium. Breakfast at [Cafe Two70](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html#dining-card). Reading. Lunch. Afternoon trivia. Dinner at [Giovanni's](/restaurants.html) or the [main dining room](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html#dining-card). [Two70 show](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html). Nightcap. Sleep. Repeat.

My husband — the one who thought we'd be bored — asked on day seven: "Can we do this again next year?"

**Why Anthem works for transatlantic:** The ship is mid-sized enough to feel navigable (you learn it in two days) but large enough to have variety. Two70 shows are excellent evening entertainment. The Solarium stays peaceful even on sea days. And the [North Star](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html) on a mid-Atlantic sunset is something you don't forget.

Transatlantic sailings are often cheaper per night than standard cruises. They reposition the ship seasonally (Southampton summers, Caribbean winters), so availability is limited. Book early if you find one.

See our [planning guide](/planning.html) for booking strategies and [solo cruising](/solo/why-i-started-solo-cruising.html) for transatlantic alone.

stories.title: The Widower Who Rode the North Star Alone
stories.intended_reader: Recent widows/widowers considering solo travel as part of healing
stories.core_insight: Anthem's North Star observation capsule offers solitary perspective that helps process grief
stories.markdown:
**Margaret died eight months before I booked Anthem.**

Forty-two years married. Then suddenly: alone. Our kids kept saying "get out of the house," but where? Everything reminded me of her. The grocery store where we shopped. The church we attended. Even the TV shows we watched together.

I booked Anthem because Margaret had circled it in a cruise magazine. "Look at that glass capsule," she'd said. "I want to ride that." We never did.

The first three days, I ate alone at the [main dining room](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html#dining-card). The servers were kind, but pity is lonely company. I spent hours in [Two70](/ships/rcl/anthem-of-the-seas.html), the venue with floor-to-ceiling windows, watching the ocean. Margaret would have loved it.

I almost didn't book the [North Star](https://www.royalcaribbean.com/cruise-ships/anthem-of-the-seas). "For couples," I thought. But at 4am one night, insomnia won. I went to guest services and reserved the first morning slot — solo.

300 feet above the ship. Glass capsule. Open ocean in every direction. Just me and the sunrise.

And for the first time since Margaret died, I felt peace instead of absence. Not happiness — peace. The kind that comes from perspective, from realizing how vast the world is and how small our grief, even when it fills every room.

I rode the North Star three more times that cruise. Always alone. Always early morning. Each time, I told Margaret what I saw. The coastline. The clouds. The way the ocean changes color at dawn.

I'm not healed. Healing isn't linear. But Anthem gave me something I needed: permission to grieve *and* to keep living. See [Cruising in the Wake of Grief](/solo/in-the-wake-of-grief.html) for more on healing through travel.

*If you or someone you know is struggling, please reach out: National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 988 (US) or Crisis Text Line: text HOME to 741741.*

stories.title: Solo at 300 Feet Above the Ocean
stories.core_insight: Anthem's solo-friendly design creates connection without forced socialization
stories.markdown:
I booked Anthem specifically for its solo traveler accommodations. The Studio staterooms designed for single occupancy meant no paying double for an empty bed, and the private Studio Lounge provided a gathering spot for fellow solo cruisers.

Morning coffee in the Studio Lounge became my daily ritual. Fellow travelers shared port tips and dinner companions. The atmosphere was naturally social without the forced activities some cruises push on singles.

North Star at sunset became my personal meditation. Rising 300 feet above the ship, alone in the glass capsule, watching the horizon stretch endlessly—that solitude felt earned rather than lonely. The crew member operating the capsule gave me extra time when he noticed my camera.

Dynamic Dining worked perfectly for solo travelers. No assigned tables meant flexibility—some nights I joined newly made friends, others I dined alone with a book, perfectly content.

Anthem showed me solo cruising isn't about being alone. It's about choosing when to connect and when to retreat. Both options exist here without judgment.

stories.title: Our Multi-Generational Anthem Adventure
stories.core_insight: Anthem's activity variety keeps all ages engaged without requiring constant togetherness
stories.markdown:
Three generations aboard Anthem: grandparents in their seventies, parents in the forties, teenagers, and a seven-year-old. Everyone doubted the plan would work.

The ship's variety saved us. Grandparents claimed the Solarium as their peaceful domain—adults only, climate controlled, comfortable loungers with ocean views. They read books there while teens dominated the FlowRider and SeaPlex.

Family dinners united us nightly. Dynamic Dining meant flexibility—some nights all twelve at one table, others we split by interest. Kids wanted burgers at Johnny Rockets while adults preferred specialty dining.

North Star became our family moment. All twelve of us booked the same session, three generations rising above the ocean together. My father-in-law, who rarely expresses emotion, quietly said: "This is why we came."

RipCord conquered my teenager's fear of heights. Watching her fly—literally fly—in that wind tunnel became the trip's defining memory. Even her younger brother, too small for RipCord, cheered from the observation deck.

stories.title: Honeymoon Heights on Anthem
stories.core_insight: Anthem's romantic venues work best when you discover them accidentally
stories.markdown:
We chose Anthem for our honeymoon because the reviews promised innovation. North Star at sunset. Two70's transforming entertainment. Technology that enhances rather than replaces romance.

Our Grand Loft Suite provided the private retreat honeymoons require—two floors of space, floor-to-ceiling windows, a balcony where we watched the sunrise with room service coffee.

But the unplanned moments defined our trip. Discovering Two70 at midnight, completely empty, the venue's glass walls reflecting stars and ship's wake. A crew member appeared with champagne: "Honeymooners?" We must have been obvious.

North Star at sunset felt obligatory until we experienced it. Rising 300 feet above the ocean, just the two of us in that glass capsule, the world reduced to water and sky and each other. Neither of us spoke. Neither of us needed to.

Wonderland dinner challenged our palates with whimsy. Courses that changed color, presentations that surprised, conversation that flowed because the restaurant refused to let us be bored.

stories.title: Navigating Tech at 72
stories.intended_reader: Older travelers uncertain about technology-focused ships
stories.core_insight: Anthem's technology simplifies cruising once you invest time learning it
stories.markdown:
My children thought Anthem would overwhelm me. At seventy-two, I still preferred paper maps and landline phones. Apps were for their generation.

The first day validated their concerns. Wristbands for doors. Apps for reservations. Digital menus that changed before I finished reading. Guest Services had a line of confused seniors.

Then I met Rodriguez at the tech desk. Patient beyond measure, he spent an hour teaching me the Royal iQ app. Not rushing, not condescending—just careful explanation until the logic clicked.

By day three, I understood. The app meant no memorizing deck locations—maps showed exactly where to go. No paper schedules to lose—everything stored digitally. No lines for reservations—everything booked from my room.

The Solarium became my sanctuary. Adults only, peaceful, with staff who remembered my coffee order by day two. I read four books that cruise—more than the previous year combined.

North Star terrified me initially. But Rodriguez appeared at my elbow: "Shall I ride with you the first time?" He did. And I understood why my grandchildren called it magical.

stories.title: A Veteran's View from North Star
stories.core_insight: Anthem's engineering excellence resonates with those who appreciate precision
stories.markdown:
Twenty-two years Navy taught me to appreciate engineering. Anthem delivered on every deck.

North Star particularly impressed me. Rising 300 feet above the ocean on a boom arm while the ship moves through waves requires precision engineering. I asked the operator about hydraulics, safety systems, failure modes. He answered every question, proud of his technology.

The bridge tour revealed similar excellence. Navigation systems integrated radar, GPS, and satellite data in ways that would have seemed science fiction during my service. Officers explained procedures with discipline I recognized—checklists, redundancies, protocols.

I found fellow veterans throughout the voyage. We gathered at Schooner Bar evenings, sharing stories civilians couldn't follow. The crew included military from multiple nations—Royal Navy, Philippine Armed Forces, Israeli Defense Forces. We shared language beyond words.

The captain's brief Veterans Day acknowledgment meant more than elaborate ceremonies would have. Simple recognition that some passengers had served. Exactly right.

stories.title: My First Cruise Exceeded Every Expectation
stories.core_insight: Anthem's abundance becomes manageable when you stop trying to do everything
stories.markdown:
I almost didn't book. Websites overwhelmed me with options. Stateroom categories, dining packages, excursion choices. My travel agent finally said: "Pick a date and a room. The rest figures itself out."

Boarding day was chaos. Terminology I didn't know. Muster stations, Royal iQ, Dynamic Dining—lingo that assumed cruise experience I lacked.

By day two, patterns emerged. Breakfast at Windjammer (casual buffet) or café (quick). Lunch wherever hunger struck. Dinner reservations through the app I finally mastered.

I tried doing everything initially. Exhausted myself completely. Missed the North Star sunset I actually wanted because I was attending trivia I didn't care about.

By day four, I learned: choose two or three things daily. Let the rest happen or not. The ship continues sailing whether you attend every event or none.

Sea days became favorites. No port pressure. Just ship, ocean, and time to explore without rushing. I found the Solarium wandering. Found Two70 seeking quiet. Found conversation at Bionic Bar seeking company.

The ship isn't going anywhere without you. Neither are the experiences.
